div.ab: zōt ud rāspīg: Anklesaria, Kotwal and Boyd, Geldner.

RecitationInstruction.ab: aṣ̌əm vohū III gwptn'] 5, 6, 15, 40, 83, 88, 672; aṣ̌əm vohū III 100, 110,231, 234, 235, 677; aṣ̌əm vohū vahištəm astī ... slyšʾmlwtyk gwbšn' 400, 410, 510.

Quotations.ab: Cf. N28.46a Kotwal and Kreyenbroek, 2003 pp. 104-105:

pad hōmāst' bun ēsm ud bōy ēw tāy az dašn be nihišn u-š hōm ud urwarām pad candīh be paydāgēnišn hōm pad kamistīh sē grih ud pad wēšištīg *5. ṣ̌ōpaθ. pad dawāzdah-hōmāst-ē tašt-ē enyā urwarām ī andar ān pad nēmag u-š hamē xwarišn

"At the beginning of the Hōmāst, (the rāspīg) has to put a piece of fire wood and incense (on the fire) and has to present the hōm and the urwarām in a certain quantity: at least three pieces and at most five. ṣ̌ōpaθ. For the Dawāzdah-Hōmāst, a whole bowl. Moreover, the urwarām in the saucer until the middle. He has to drink the whole.

ModernPractice.ab: "The chief priest, taking the libation wire, wetting (it) in the milk saucer, touching it to the date-palm leaf of the bundle while wetting it, he recites with the assistant priest.
